newsitem.title: USA: Ballot questions and bond referendums by state.
newsitem.headline: Ballot questions and bond referendums by state.

text.p: --$2 billion Los Angeles Unified School District, Calif., school bonds.
--$995 million, California Proposition 204 - Safe, Clean, Reliable Water Supply Act. Would authorize the issuance of general obligation bonds to finance water programs.
--$750 million Los Angeles, Calif., park bonds.

--$700 million, California Proposition 205 - Youthful and Adult Offender Local Facilities Bond Act of 1996. Would authorize the issuance of general obligation bonds to construct and renovate county juvenile and adult correctional facilities.
--$400 million, Proposition 206 - Veterans' Bond Act of 1996. Would authorize the issuance of general obligation bonds to fund a program of farm, home and mobile home loans.
--$319 million Los Angeles County, Calif., greenbelt, zoo improvement bonds.
--$225 million Sacramento Unified School District, Calif., school GO bonds.
--Proposition 210 - Minimum Wage Increase. Increases the current state minimum wage of $4.25 per hour to $5.00 per hour on March 1, 1997 and then to $5.75 per hour on March 1, 1998.
--Proposition 217 - Top Income Tax Brackets. Continues highest tax rates of 10 percent and 11 percent on residents with taxable income over $100,000 and $200,000 respectively.

--Proposition 218 - Voter Approval for Local Government Taxes. Limits authority of local governments to impose taxes and property-related assessments, fees and charges. Requires majority of voters approve increases in general taxes and reiterates that two-thirds must approve special taxes. COLORADO
--$100 million Colorado Springs, Colo., school bonds. CONNECTICUT DELAWARE FLORIDA
--$200 million Dade County, Fla., GOs for parks.
--Dade County, Fla., votes on whether tax money can be used to build $165 million basketball arena for Miami Heat.
--Referendum on proposal requiring two-thirds voter approval for statewide tax increases.
--Escambia County, Fla., votes on property tax increase to fund land preservation.
--$115 million of Richmond Cty, Ga, GOs for schools.
--$30 million Cobb County, Ga., GOs for recreation.
--Gwinnett County, Ga., votes on a one-cent sales tax increase to finance park, library and public safety projects.
--Referendum on proposal allowing school systems to use sales tax money for construction.
--Referendum on proposal to end intangibles tax.
Voters in 19 Illinois counties will be asked to approve a limit on local property tax increases.
Under the measure, annualincreases in local property tax collections would be capped at five percent or the rate of inflation, whichever is less.

The restriction would also prohibit the issuance of general obligation debt without voter approval. Counties slated to hold tax cap elections are: Boone, Champaign, Christian, Franklin, Jackson, Kankakee, Lee, Logan, Macoupin, Massac, Menard, Monroe,Morgan, Randolph, Sangamon, Schuyler, Union, Williamson and Winnebago.
--State parishes vote whether to keep gambling legal. MAINE
Maine is planning to ask its voters to approve or reject a total of around $40 million of bond initiatives:
--$16.5 million to clean up public health, hazardous substance discharge sites, including tire stockpiles, with $9 million set aside for drinking water grants for cities and towns.
--$11 million to encourage job growth and economic vitality by helping agricultural enterprises and small businesses get capital.
--$10 million to clean up water pollution and drinking water problems.
--$3 million for capital improvements at state parks.
--$89.6 million Baltimore County, Md., GOs for schools.
--Prince George's County, Md., vote on proposal to repeal property tax cap.

--Wayne County, Mich. - Voter approval for one percent hotel/motel tax, two percent car rental tax. Revenues from tax would pay off $80 million of bonds that would be sold to help finance a new $225 million domed stadium for the Detroit Lions football team in downtown Detroit.
--$23 million Harrison County, Miss., GOs for schools.
--$6.4 million west Jasper Cty, Miss., GOs for schools. MISSOURI
--Proposed constitutional amendments to limit local property taxes and make quality education a fundamental right.
--$3.1 million East Amwell, N.J., school renovation bonds.
--Proposed constitutional amendment to dedicate four percent of corporate business taxes each year to environmental projects.
--$12 million Sante Fe, N.M., bond measure to fund public works projects.
--$1.75 billion New York Clean Water, Clean Air Bond Act. Would fund a variety of environmental projects through-out the state.
--Constitutional amendment to give governor veto powers.
--$98.4 million Charlotte, N.C., GOs for streets and drainage.
--$86.3 million Durham, N.C., GOs for streets, parks, housing and arts.
--$25 million Greensboro, N.C., GOs for public safety.
--$13.5 million Chapel Hill, N.C., GOs for parks, streets and sidewalks.
--$11.5 million Wilmington, N.C., GOs for stormwater drainage, parks and roads.
--$10 million Greensboro, N.C., GOs for housing.
--13.5 mill property tax operating levy for Cleveland Public Schools. OKLAHOMA
--$94.5 million Tulsa Independent School District, Okla., GO school bonds.
--Constitutional amendment allowing state pension money to be invested in equities.
--Lexington County, S.C., to decide whether county should have power to use general fund revenues and property taxes to operate water and sewer systems.
--Dorchester County, S.C., votes on local-option sales tax to offset property taxes.
--Berkeley County, S.C., votes on local-option sales tax to offset property taxes.
--Knoxville and Knox County, Tenn., vote on proposal to consolidate government.
--$174.6 million Richardson Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$4 million Community Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$2.5 million Lipan Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$85 million Humble Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds
--$66.8 million LaPorte Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$44.125 million Lake Travis Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$11 million Hillsboro Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$20 million Jasper Independent School District, Texas, GO school bonds.
--$9.9 million Washington County, Utah, GO bonds for a jail.
--$174.8 million Chesterfield County, Va., GOs for schools.
--$43.8 million Arlington County, Va., county government GOs.
--$34 million Chesterfield County, Va., GOs for public safety.
--$29.1 million Arlington County, Va., GO school bonds.
--$10.3 million Chesterfield County, Va., GOs for libraries.
--$9.3 million Chesterfield County, Va., GOs for parks. WASHINGTON

--$3.9 billion, 10-year plan to build a 25-mile "starter" light rail system, develop 81 miles of commuter rail lines and improve bus service and highway express lanes, in Seattle, Wash. About $1.05 billion would be raised by issuing bonds. WEST VIRGINIA
--$15 million Platteville School District, Wis., building bond issue.
